abstract.p: Two nonprofit groups say that average New Jersey family could cut its gasoline costs in half if Congress enacts tougher fuel efficiency standards recommended by Presidential committee; in 1995, committee urged lawmakers to increase mileage standards to 45 miles per gallon from 27 for cars and 34 miles per gallon from 20.7 for light trucks by 2008 (S)

block.p: The average New Jersey family could cut its gasoline costs in half if Congress enacted the tougher fuel efficiency standards recommended by a Presidential advisory committee, two nonprofit groups said yesterday.
In 1995, the committee urged lawmakers to increase mileage standards to 45 miles per gallon from 27 for cars and 34 miles per gallon from 20.7 for light trucks by 2008.

The average New Jersey family could cut its gasoline costs in half if Congress enacted the tougher fuel efficiency standards recommended by a Presidential advisory committee, two nonprofit groups said yesterday.
In 1995, the committee urged lawmakers to increase mileage standards to 45 miles per gallon from 27 for cars and 34 miles per gallon from 20.7 for light trucks by 2008.

The stricter standards would shave $540 off the average New Jersey family's annual gas bill of $1,039, according to a report released yesterday by the Environmental Working Group and the Surface Transportation Policy Project, a group that promotes spending on transportation projects. Raising the standards would reduce the state's carbon dioxide emissions by 15 million tons a year, the report said.

But the costs of meeting those standards would raise the average price of a new car by $2,500, said Ron DeFore of the Coalition for Vehicle Choice, which represents the three largest United States auto makers.
